title: Joe Thompson vows to achieve 'most important win of all' after Rochdale midfielder confirms cancer return
text:

Joe Thompson has confirmed the return of his cancer in a statement published on the Rochdale website. 
The 28-year-old has previously successfully battled the disease and vowed to do the same a second time, while making special mention of all the support he has received from his family, the League One club and the world of football since learning his illness has returned. 
"I will fight this life hurdle with he same belief, courage and desire as my previous battle," said Thompson. 
"I would like to thank my wife, Chantelle, who was my rock in my first encounter and will once again be by my side with the same encouragement, discipline and strength. He's been playing some of his best football since returning to his boyhood club (Photo: ProSports/REX/Shutterstock) 
Joe Thompson diagnosed with rare cancer aged just 24 
"Not to mention the love shown to me by both my wife and beautiful daughter Thailula-Lily who are both my motivations daily." 
The Rochdale midfielder had kind words for the club to which he returned at the beginning of the season, after four years away during which he signed for Tranmere Rovers, Bury and Carlisle United, as well as completing loan spells with Wrexham and Southport. 
"I would also like to thank the Manager and his Staff, there are no words to describe this group of people," he said. 
"They gave me an opportunity at the beginning of the season and I hope I have repaid their faith in me with what some say is the best form of my career. Thompson has vowed to beat the illness just like he did last time (Photo: ProSports/REX/Shutterstock) 
"Also, to my teammates, this unique group of Players who all believe in each other and keep on over achieving." 
Thompson also thanked the Board, Rochdale's fans, as well as the players' union and the PFA. 
"To the Board and the fans of my hometown Club which I am so honoured to have returned to and so proud to wear the shirt of, thank you for the warmth and support you shown me upon my return and continue to do so," he continued. 
"A big thank you to my Union too, the PFA, especially John Bramhall. Their support commenced within hours of my diagnosis and me and my family are extremely grateful. 
"I came back from a goal down before, not only to equalise, but to take the lead. 
"This illness may have found an equaliser but the quest for me to get the winner starts today and I can assure you I will get the most important win of all time. Thank you to you all." Like us on Facebook
